newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan May trade surplus down 10.4 percent yr/yr.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan May trade surplus down 10.4 percent yr/yr.

text.p: Taiwan had a trade surplus of US$1.599 billion in May, down 10.4 percent from May 1996's surplus of US$1.784 billion, the finance ministry said on Saturday.
Exports in May totalled $10.16 billion, up 6.4 percent from May 1996, the ministry said in a statement.
Taiwan's May imports rose an annual 10.2 percent to $8.56 billion, it said.
The May trade surplus of $1.599 billion was higher than the average forecast for a surplus of $1.1325 billion compiled from a Reuters Poll of Taiwan economists on June 4.

Hong Kong surpassed the United States in May to become Taiwan's top export market -- one of the clearest indications to date of communist China's growing importance to rival Taiwan's economy. Much of Hong Kong's imports are destined for China.
May exports to Hong Kong accounted for 24.1 percent of Taiwan's total exports and a 9.3 percent increase from May 1996 to $2.444 billion.
Hsu Kuo-chung, the ministry's chief statistician, said Hong Kong's ouster of the United States as an export destination would be short-lived.

"It will only be a temporary phenomenon for Hong Kong to be Taiwan's top export market," Hsu told reporters after the trade data announcement. "For all of 1997, we expect the United States will still be Taiwan's biggest export destination."
Hsu said he did not expect the British colony's July 1 handover to China to have a major impact on Taiwan's trade with Hong Kong. He did not elaborate.

Nationalist Taiwan, viewed by Beijing as a renegade province since a civil war split them in 1949, has allowed indirect trade and other indirect ties since a late 1980s political thaw. Flows of Taiwan trade and investment into the mainland have surged.

Taiwan's May exports to the United States totalled $2.35 billion, accounting for 23.2 percent of the total exports or 9.7 percent rise from a year ago. Exports to Europe stood at $1.52 billion in May, representing 15 percent of the total.

Japan remained Taiwan's top import source, accounting for $2.12 billion or 24.8 percent of the total, followed by the United States at $1.83 billion (21.3 percent) and Europe at $1.55 billion (18.1 percent).
Taiwan expects to see higher import growth due to persistent and strong domestic demand in the recovering economy, Hsu said.
"This year's import growth will be higher than that of exports. As a result, our trade surplus will shrink," Hsu said.
Taiwan's May trade surplus with the United States was down 5.9 percent at $520 million from the same month a year ago.
Its trade surplus with Hong Kong, as always the main conduit for Taiwan's lucrative and growing unofficial trade with rival China, increased 9.3 percent at $2.29 billion.
Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan was $1.11 billion, up 27.4 percent from May 1996.
